title: Ops Resilience: Restoration Race
description: Grid secured. Now comes the hard part: restoring power to 200,000 homes and businesses without triggering another cascade failure. Every decision affects real people.

software-engineer.title: Deploy the Recovery Scripts
software-engineer.instruction: You've written automated scripts to restore each substation safely. But they must run in a specific sequence or you risk overloading the still-healthy sections of the grid. Put the restoration sequence in order.

items.label: Verify all compromised substations have been wiped and reimaged
Restore the backbone transmission substations that feed multiple zones
Bring up a test load to verify the backbone can handle demand
Sequentially restore district-level substations in order of hospital and critical service priority
Restore residential areas last in order of grid zone capacity

data-scientist.title: Predict Safe Restoration Rate
data-scientist.instruction: Restoring power too fast can overload transformer lines. Based on the load increase capacity tests over the last 4 hours (percentage of normal load the grid accepted safely), predict the maximum safe restoration percentage per hour to avoid a cascade failure.

cloud-engineer.title: Rebuild or Patch the SCADA Systems
cloud-engineer.instruction: The compromised SCADA systems need to be secured before they go back online. You have two options and time is critical because people are still without power.

options.label: Full rebuild from a known clean image. Every compromised node gets a fresh OS install and config. Takes 6 hours but you're 100% sure the attacker left no traces.
Forensic patching: surgically remove only the identified malware and close the specific vulnerabilities exploited. Faster (2 hours) but there's a 15% chance of missing something.
Bring systems back online under intense monitoring. If the attacker is still hiding, they'll reveal themselves when they try to move. Very risky but gives the best intelligence.
Replace the physical hardware entirely. Most expensive and takes 12 hours but removes any possibility of firmware-level persistence.
